{{short description|Counseling form developed by Steven Hayes in 1982}} {{Mindfulness}} '''Acceptance and commitment therapy''' ('''ACT''', typically pronounced as the word "act") is a form of counseling and a branch of [[clinical behavior analysis]].<ref name="Plumb">{{cite journal | title=In Search of Meaning: Values in Modern Clinical Behavior Analysis |author1=Jennifer C Plumb |author2=Ian Stewart |author3=Galway JoAnne Dahl |author4=Tobias Lundgren | journal=Behav Anal. |date=Spring 2009 | volume=32 | issue=1 | pages=85–103 | pmc=2686995 | pmid=22478515 | doi=10.1007/bf03392177}}</ref> It is an [[empirical]]ly-based [[psychological]] [[intervention (counseling)|intervention]] that uses [[acceptance]] and [[mindfulness]] strategies mixed in different ways<ref name="act">{{cite web |last=Hayes |first=Steven |authorlink=Steven C. Hayes |title=Acceptance & Commitment Therapy (ACT) |publisher=ContextualPsychology.org |url= http://www.contextualpsychology.org/act}}</ref> with commitment and behavior-change strategies, to increase [[psychological flexibility]]. The approach was originally called ''comprehensive distancing''.<ref name="baojournal.com">{{cite journal |last1=Zettle |first1=Robert D. |year=2005 |title=The Evolution of a Contextual Approach to Therapy: From Comprehensive Distancing to ACT |journal=International Journal of Behavioral Consultation and Therapy |volume=1 |issue=2 |pages=77–89 |url=http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/search/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=EJ844315&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=EJ844315}}</ref> [[Steven C. Hayes]] developed Acceptance and Commitment Therapy in 1982 in order to create a mixed approach which integrates both cognitive and behavioral therapy.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Cognitive and Behavioral Theories in Clinical Practice|last=Freeman|first=Arthur|publisher=The Guilford Press|year=2010|isbn=978-1-60623-342-9|location=Newyork, NY|pages=125}}</ref> There are a variety of protocols for ACT, depending on the target behavior or setting. For example, in behavioral health areas a [[Brief psychotherapy|brief]] version of ACT is called ''focused acceptance and commitment therapy'' (FACT).<ref>{{cite web |title=Focused Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (FACT): Mastering The Basics |url=https://contextualscience.org/wc12_strosahl_robinson_gustavsson |publisher=[[Association for Contextual Behavioral Science]] |website=contextualscience.org |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407201937/https://contextualscience.org/wc12_strosahl_robinson_gustavsson |archivedate=2016-04-07 |accessdate=2016-04-07}}</ref>
The objective of ACT is not elimination of difficult feelings; rather, it is to be present with what life brings us and to "move toward valued behavior".<ref>{{cite book|author=Hayes, Steven C. |author2=Strosahl, Kirk D. |author3=Wilson, Kelly G.|title=Acceptance and Commitment Therapy: The Process and Practice of Mindful Change|publisher=Guilford Press|location=New York|year=2012|isbn=978-1-60918-962-4|edition=2|page=240}}</ref> Acceptance and commitment therapy invites people to open up to unpleasant feelings, and learn not to overreact to them, and not avoid situations where they are invoked. Its therapeutic effect is a positive spiral where feeling better leads to a better understanding of the truth.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Shpancer |first= Noam |date= September 8, 2010 |title= Emotional Acceptance: Why Feeling Bad is Good |journal=Psychology Today |URL= http://m.psychologytoday.com/blog/insight-therapy/201009/emotional-acceptance-why-feeling-bad-is-good}}</ref> In ACT, 'truth' is measured through the concept of 'workability', or what works to take another step toward what matters (e.g. values, meaning).
==Technique== ===Basics=== ACT is developed within a [[pragmatism|pragmatic]] philosophy called [[functional contextualism]]. ACT is based on [[relational frame theory]] (RFT), a comprehensive theory of language and cognition that is an offshoot of [[behavior analysis]]. Both ACT and RFT are based on [[B. F. Skinner|B. F. Skinner's]] philosophy of [[Radical behaviorism|Radical Behaviorism]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kohlenberg|first=Robert|last2=Hayes|first2=Steven|last3=Tsai|first3=Mavis|year=1993|title=Radical Behavioral Psychotherapy: Two Contemporary Examples|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.542.4819&rep=rep1&type=pdf|journal=Clinical Psychology Review|volume=13|pages=579–592|via=|doi=10.1016/0272-7358(93)90047-p}}</ref>
ACT differs from traditional [[cognitive behavioral therapy]] (CBT) in that rather than trying to teach people to better control their thoughts, feelings, sensations, memories and other private events, ACT teaches them to "just notice," accept, and embrace their private events, especially previously unwanted ones. ACT helps the individual get in contact with a [[transcendence (philosophy)|transcendent]] sense of self known as "self-as-context"—the you who is always there observing and experiencing and yet distinct from one's thoughts, feelings, sensations, and memories. ACT aims to help the individual clarify their personal values and to take action on them, bringing more vitality and meaning to their life in the process, increasing their [[psychological flexibility]].<ref name="baojournal.com"/>
While Western psychology has typically operated under the "healthy normality" assumption which states that by their nature, humans are psychologically healthy, ACT assumes, rather, that psychological processes of a normal human mind are often destructive.<ref name="Harris"/> The core conception of ACT is that psychological suffering is usually caused by [[experiential avoidance]], cognitive entanglement, and resulting psychological rigidity that leads to a failure to take needed behavioral steps in accord with core values. As a simple way to summarize the model, ACT views the core of many problems to be due to the concepts represented in the acronym, '''FEAR''':{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}[[File:Cards used as a therapeutic activity in ACT treatment.jpg|thumb|Cards used as a therapeutic activity in ACT treatment.]] * '''F'''usion with your thoughts * '''E'''valuation of experience * '''A'''voidance of your experience * '''R'''eason-giving for your behavior
And the healthy alternative is to '''ACT''': * '''A'''ccept your reactions and be present * '''C'''hoose a valued direction * '''T'''ake action
===Core principles=== ACT commonly employs six core principles to help clients develop [[psychological flexibility]]:<ref name="Harris">{{cite journal |last=Harris |first=Russ |date=August 2006 |title=Embracing your demons: an overview of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy |journal=Psychotherapy in Australia |volume=12 |issue=4 |pages=2–8 |url=http://actmindfully.com.au/upimages/Dr_Russ_Harris_-_A_Non-technical_Overview_of_ACT.pdf}}</ref> # Cognitive defusion: Learning methods to reduce the tendency to [[Reification (fallacy)|reify]] thoughts, images, emotions, and memories. # Acceptance: Allowing unwanted private experiences (thoughts, feelings and urges) to come and go without struggling with them. # Contact with the present moment: Awareness of the here and now, experienced with openness, interest, and receptiveness. (e.g., mindfulness) # The observing self: Accessing a transcendent sense of self, a continuity of consciousness which is unchanging. # Values: Discovering what is most important to oneself.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Hank |last1=Robb |year=2007 |title=Values as Leading Principles in Acceptance and Commitment Therapy |journal=International Journal of Behavioral Consultation and Therapy |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=118–23 |url=http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/search/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=EJ801192&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=EJ801192 |doi=10.1037/h0100170}}</ref> # Committed action: Setting goals according to values and carrying them out responsibly, in the service of a meaningful life.
Correlational evidence has found that absence of psychological flexibility predicts many forms of psychopathology. A 2005 [[meta-analysis]] showed that the six ACT principles, on average, account for 16–29% of the variance in psychopathology (general mental health, depression, anxiety) at baseline, depending on the measure, using correlational methods.<ref name=hayes06 />{{rp|12–13}} A 2012 meta-analysis of 68 laboratory-based studies on ACT components has also provided support for the link between psychological flexibility concepts and specific components.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.beth.2012.05.003 |title=The Impact of Treatment Components Suggested by the Psychological Flexibility Model: A Meta-Analysis of Laboratory-Based Component Studies |year=2012 |last1=Levin |first1=Michael E. |last2=Hildebrandt |first2=Mikaela J. |last3=Lillis |first3=Jason |last4=Hayes |first4=Steven C. |journal=Behavior Therapy |volume=43 |issue=4 |pages=741–56 |pmid=23046777}}</ref>
==Research== A 2008 meta-analysis concluded that the evidence was still too limited for ACT to be considered a supported treatment, and raised methodological concerns about the research base.<ref name="Ost2008">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.brat.2007.12.005 |title=Efficacy of the third wave of behavioral therapies: A systematic review and meta-analysis |year=2008 |last=Öst |first=Lars-Göran |journal=Behaviour Research and Therapy |volume=46 |issue=3 |pages=296–321 |pmid=18258216}}</ref> A 2009 meta-analysis found that ACT was more effective than placebo and "treatment as usual" for most problems (with the exception of anxiety and depression), but not more effective than CBT and other traditional therapies.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Powers MB, Zum Vörde Sive Vörding MB, Emmelkamp PM | year = 2009 | title = Acceptance and commitment therapy: A meta-analytic review. | journal = Psychotherapy and Psychosomatics | volume = 78 | pages = 73–80 | doi=10.1159/000190790}}</ref> A 2012 meta-analysis was more positive and reported that ACT outperformed CBT, except for treating depression and anxiety.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Ruiz, F. J. | year = 2012 | title = Acceptance and commitment therapy versus traditional cognitive behavioral therapy: A systematic review and meta-analysis of current empirical evidence | journal = International Journal of Psychology and Psychological Therapy | volume = 12 | issue = 3 | pages = 333–358}}</ref>
A 2015 review found that ACT was better than placebo and typical treatment for [[anxiety disorders]], [[Depression (mood)|depression]], and [[addiction]].<ref name="davis2015"/> Its effectiveness was similar to traditional treatments like cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT).<ref name="davis2015">{{cite journal|last1=A-Tjak|first1=JG|last2=Davis|first2=ML|last3=Morina|first3=N|last4=Powers|first4=MB|last5=Smits|first5=JA|last6=Emmelkamp|first6=PM|title=A meta-analysis of the efficacy of acceptance and commitment therapy for clinically relevant mental and physical health problems.|journal=Psychotherapy and psychosomatics|date=2015|volume=84|issue=1|pages=30–6|pmid=25547522|doi=10.1159/000365764}}</ref> The authors suggested that the CBT comparison of the previous 2012 meta-analysis may have been compromised by the inclusion of [[Randomized controlled trial|nonrandomized trials]] with small sample sizes. They also noted that research methodologies had improved since the studies described in the 2008 meta-analysis.<ref name="davis2015" />
The number of [[randomized clinical trial]]s and controlled time series evaluating ACT for a variety of problems is growing. In 2006, only about 30 such studies were known,<ref name=hayes06>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.brat.2005.06.006 |title=Acceptance and Commitment Therapy: Model, processes and outcomes |year=2006 |last1=Hayes |first1=Steven C. |last2=Luoma |first2=Jason B. |last3=Bond |first3=Frank W. |last4=Masuda |first4=Akihiko |last5=Lillis |first5=Jason |journal=Behaviour Research and Therapy |volume=44 |pages=1–25 |pmid=16300724 |issue=1}}</ref> but in 2011 the number had approximately doubled.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Ruiz |first=F. J. |year=2010 |title=A review of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) empirical evidence: Correlational, experimental psychopathology, component and outcome studies |journal=International Journal of Psychology and Psychological Therapy |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages=125–62 |url=http://www.ijpsy.com/volumen10/num1/256.html}}</ref> The website of the [[Association for Contextual Behavioral Science]] states that there were 171 randomized controlled trials (RCTs) of ACT published as of December 2016,<ref name="ACBS evidence">{{cite web |last=Hayes |first=Steven C. |authorlink=Steven C. Hayes |url=https://contextualscience.org/state_of_the_act_evidence |title=State of the ACT Evidence |website=contextualscience.org |publisher=[[Association for Contextual Behavioral Science]] |accessdate=2017-05-30}}</ref> and over 20 meta-analyses and 45 mediational studies of the ACT literature as of Spring 2016.<ref name="ACBS evidence"/> Most studies of ACT so far have been conducted on adults and therefore the knowledge of its effectiveness when applied to children and adolescents is limited.
==Similarities== ACT, [[dialectical behavior therapy]] (DBT), [[functional analytic psychotherapy]] (FAP), [[mindfulness-based cognitive therapy]] (MBCT) and other acceptance- and mindfulness-based approaches are commonly grouped under the name "the third wave of cognitive behavior therapy".<ref name="Ost2008"/><ref>{{Cite book |first=Christopher R. |last=Martell |author2=Michael E. Addis|author3=Neil S. Jacobson |year=2001 |title=Depression in Context: Strategies for Guided Action |publisher=W. W. Norton |isbn=0-393-70350-9 |location=New York |page=197}}</ref> The first wave, [[behaviour therapy]], commenced in the 1920s based on Pavlov's [[Classical conditioning|classical (respondent) conditioning]] and [[operant conditioning]] that was correlated to reinforcing consequences. The second wave emerged in the 1970s and included cognition in the form of irrational beliefs, dysfunctional attitudes or depressogenic attributions.<ref name="Leahy, R. L. 2004">Leahy, R. L. (2004). Contemporary cognitive therapy: Theory, research, and practice. New York, NY: Guilford Press.</ref> In the late 1980s empirical limitations and philosophical misgivings of the second wave gave rise to Steven Hayes' ACT theory which modified the focus of abnormal behaviour away from the content or form towards the context in which it occurs.<ref name="Leahy, R. L. 2004"/> ACT research has suggested that many of the [[Defence mechanisms|emotional defenses]] individuals use with conviction to try to solve their problems actually entangle humans into greater suffering. Rigid ideas about themselves, lack of focus on what is important in their life and struggling to change sensations, feelings or thoughts that are troublesome only serve to create greater distress.<ref>Hayes, S. C., & Smith, S. (2005). Get Out of Your Mind and into Your Life: The New Acceptance and Commitment Therapy. Santa Rosa, CA: New Harbinger Publications.</ref>
[[Steven C. Hayes]] described this group in his [[Association for Behavioral and Cognitive Therapies|ABCT]] President Address as follows:
{{quote|Grounded in an empirical, principle-focused approach, the third wave of behavioral and cognitive therapy is particularly sensitive to the context and functions of psychological phenomena, not just their form, and thus tends to emphasize contextual and experiential change strategies in addition to more direct and didactic ones. These treatments tend to seek the construction of broad, flexible and effective repertoires over an eliminative approach to narrowly defined problems, and to emphasize the relevance of the issues they examine for clinicians as well as clients. The third wave reformulates and synthesizes previous generations of behavioral and cognitive therapy and carries them forward into questions, issues, and domains previously addressed primarily by other traditions, in hopes of improving both understanding and outcomes.}}
ACT has also been adapted to create a non-therapy version of the same processes called ''Acceptance and Commitment Training''. This training process, oriented towards the development of mindfulness, acceptance, and valued skills in non-clinical settings such as businesses or schools, has also been investigated in a handful of research studies with good preliminary results.<ref>Hayes, S.C.; Bond, F.W.; Barnes-Holmes, D. & Austin, J. (2007). Acceptance And Mindfulness at Work: Applying Acceptance and Commitment Therapy And Relational Frame Theory to Organizational Behavior Management. Binghamton, NY: Haworth Press.{{page needed|date=November 2012}}</ref> This is somewhat similar to the awareness–management movement in business training programs, where [[mindfulness]] and [[cognitive-shifting]] techniques are employed.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}}
The emphasis of ACT on ongoing present moment [[awareness]], valued directions and committed action is similar to other psycho-therapeutic approaches that, unlike ACT, are not as focused on outcome research or consciously linked to a basic behavioral science program, including approaches such as [[Gestalt therapy]], [[Morita therapy]] and Voice Dialogue, [[Internal Family Systems Model|IFS]] and others.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}}
Wilson, Hayes & Byrd explore at length the compatibilities between ACT and the [[12-step]] treatment of addictions and argue that, unlike most other psychotherapies, both approaches can be implicitly or explicitly integrated due to their broad commonalities. Both approaches endorse acceptance as an alternative to unproductive control. ACT emphasizes the hopelessness of relying on ineffectual strategies to control private experience, similarly the 12-step approach emphasizes the acceptance of powerlessness over addiction. Both approaches encourage a broad life-reorientation, rather than a narrow focus on the elimination of substance use, and both place great value on the long-term project of building of a meaningful life aligned with the clients' values. ACT and 12-step both encourage the pragmatic utility of cultivating a transcendent sense of self ([[higher power]]) within an unconventional, individualized spirituality. Finally they both openly accept the paradox that acceptance is a necessary condition for change and both encourage a playful awareness of the limitations of human thinking.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Exploring Compatibilities Between Acceptance and Commitment Therapy and 12-Step Treatment for Substance Abuse|doi=10.1023/A:1007835106007 |year=2000 |last1=Wilson |first1=Kelly G. |last2=Hayes |first2=Steven C. |last3=Byrd |first3=Michelle R. |journal=Journal of Rational-Emotive and Cognitive-Behavior Therapy |volume=18 |issue=4 |pages=209–234}}</ref>
==Criticisms== {{See also|Psychotherapy#General critiques}} Some published empirical studies in clinical psychology have argued that ACT is not different from other interventions.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2007.09.003 |title=Acceptance and mindfulness-based therapy: New wave or old hat? |year=2008 |last1=Hofmann |first1=Stefan G. |last2=Asmundson |first2=Gordon J.G. |journal=Clinical Psychology Review |volume=28 |pages=1–16 |pmid=17904260 |issue=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1468-2850.2008.00137.x |title=Acceptance and commitment therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy for anxiety disorders: Different treatments, similar mechanisms? |year=2008 |last1=Arch |first1=Joanna J. |last2=Craske |first2=Michelle G. |journal=Clinical Psychology: Science and Practice |volume=15 |issue=4 |pages=263–279}}</ref> [[Stefan Hofmann]] argued that ACT is similar to the much older [[Morita therapy]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Hofmann |first=Stefan G. |date=December 2008 |title=Acceptance and commitment therapy: new wave or Morita therapy? |journal=Clinical Psychology: Science and Practice |volume=15 |issue=4 |pages=280–285 |doi=10.1111/j.1468-2850.2008.00138.x |quote=the criticism offered by ACT against CBT is based on a misrepresentation of the empirical evidence. Moreover, the strategies of ACT are not specific to the theory and philosophy underlying ACT. There are considerable similarities between ACT and Eastern holistic approaches, such as Morita therapy, which was developed 80 years ago.}}</ref>
A meta-analysis by Öst in 2008 concluded that ACT did not yet qualify as an "empirically supported treatment", that the research methodology for ACT was less stringent than cognitive behavioral therapy, and that the mean effect size was moderate.<ref name="Ost2008"/> Supporters of ACT have challenged those conclusions by showing that the quality difference in Öst's review was accounted for by the larger number of funded trials in the CBT comparison group.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.brat.2009.07.020 |title=Öst's (2008) methodological comparison of clinical trials of acceptance and commitment therapy versus cognitive behavior therapy: Matching apples with oranges? |year=2009 |last1=Gaudiano |first1=Brandon A. |journal=Behaviour Research and Therapy |volume=47 |issue=12 |pages=1066–70 |pmid=19679300 |pmc=2786237}}</ref>
Several concerns, both theoretical and empirical, have arisen in response to the ascendancy of ACT. One major theoretical concern is that the primary authors of ACT and of the corresponding theories of human behavior, relational frame theory (RFT) and functional contextualism (FC), recommend their approach as the proverbial holy grail of psychological therapies.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Routier |first=Cédric P. |date=2007 |title=Relational frame theory (RFT) and acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT): Emperor's tailors or knights of the holy grail? |journal=Acta Comportamentalia |volume=15 |issue=3 |pages=45–69 |url=http://pepsic.bvsalud.org/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0188-81452007000400004}}</ref> Psychologist [[James C. Coyne]], in a discussion of "disappointments and embarrassments in the branding of psychotherapies as evidence supported", said: "Whether or not ACT is more efficacious than other therapies, as its proponents sometimes claim, or whether it is efficacious for psychosis, is debatable".<ref>{{cite web |last=Coyne |first=James C. |authorlink=James C. Coyne |title=Troubles in the branding of psychotherapies as 'evidence supported' |url=http://blogs.plos.org/mindthebrain/2012/10/22/troubles-in-the-branding-of-psychotherapies-as-evidence-supported/ |date=22 October 2012 |website=plos.org |publisher=[[PLOS]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304014203/http://blogs.plos.org/mindthebrain/2012/10/22/troubles-in-the-branding-of-psychotherapies-as-evidence-supported/ |archivedate=4 March 2016 |accessdate=4 May 2016}}</ref> The textbook ''Systems of Psychotherapy: A Transtheoretical Analysis'' provides criticisms of third-wave behaviour therapies including ACT from the perspectives of other systems of psychotherapy.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Prochaska |first1=James O. |authorlink1=James O. Prochaska |last2=Norcross |first2=John C. |authorlink2=John C. Norcross |date=2014 |title=Systems of psychotherapy: a transtheoretical analysis |edition=8th |location=Australia; Stamford, CT |publisher=[[Cengage Learning]] |isbn=9781133314516 |oclc=851089001 |pages=[//books.google.com/books?id=PgTyAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA=310 310–312]}}</ref>
Psychologist Jonathan W. Kanter said that Hayes and colleagues "argue that empirical clinical psychology is hampered in its efforts to alleviate human suffering and present ''contextual behavioral science'' (CBS) to address the basic philosophical, theoretical and methodological shortcomings of the field. CBS represents a host of good ideas but at times the promise of CBS is obscured by excessive promotion of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) and Relational Frame Theory (RFT) and demotion of earlier cognitive and behavior change techniques in the absence of clear logic and empirical support."<ref name="Kanter">{{cite journal |last=Kanter |first=Jonathan W. |date=June 2013 |title=The vision of a progressive clinical science to guide clinical practice |journal=Behavior Therapy |volume=44 |issue=2 |pages=228–233 |doi=10.1016/j.beth.2010.07.006 |pmid=23611073 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Jonathan_Kanter2/publication/236275068_The_vision_of_a_progressive_clinical_science_to_guide_clinical_practice/links/00b7d5214dc7c2fe16000000.pdf}}</ref> Nevertheless, Kanter concluded that "the ideas of CBS, RFT, and ACT deserve serious consideration by the mainstream community and have great potential to shape a truly progressive clinical science to guide clinical practice."<ref name="Kanter"/>
ACT currently appears to be about as effective as standard CBT, with some meta-analyses showing small differences in favor of ACT and others not. For example, a meta-analysis published by Francisco Ruiz in 2012 looked at 16 studies comparing ACT to standard CBT.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Ruiz Jiménez |first=Francisco José |date=2012 |title=Acceptance and commitment therapy versus traditional cognitive behavioral therapy: A systematic review and meta-analysis of current empirical evidence |journal=International Journal of Psychology and Psychological Therapy |volume=12 |issue=3 |pages=333–358 |url=https://dialnet.unirioja.es/servlet/articulo?codigo=4019738}}</ref> ACT failed to separate from CBT on effect sizes for depression, anxiety or quality of life. The author did find separation between ACT and CBT on the "primary outcome" – a heterogeneous class of 14 separate outcome measures that were aggregated into the effect size analysis. This analysis however is limited by the highly heterogeneous nature of the outcome variables used in the analysis, which has the tendency to increase the number needed to treat (NNT) to replicate the effect size reported. More limited measures, such as depression, anxiety and quality of life decrease the NNT, making the analysis more clinically relevant, and on these measures ACT did not outperform CBT.
A 2013 paper comparing ACT to [[cognitive therapy]] (CT) concluded that "like CT, ACT cannot yet make strong claims that its unique and theory-driven intervention components are active ingredients in its effects."<ref name="HerbertForman2013">{{cite journal |last1=Herbert |first1=James D. |last2=Forman |first2=Evan M. |date=June 2013 |title=Caution: the differences between CT and ACT may be larger (and smaller) than they appear |journal=[[Behavior Therapy (journal)|Behavior Therapy]] |volume=44 |issue=2 |pages=218–223 |doi=10.1016/j.beth.2009.09.005 |pmid=23611071}}</ref> The authors of the paper suggested that many of the assumptions of ACT and CT "are pre-analytical, and cannot be directly pitted against one another in experimental tests."<ref name="HerbertForman2013"/>
==Professional organizations== The [[Association for Contextual Behavioral Science]] is committed to research and development in the area of ACT, RFT, and contextual behavioral science more generally. As of 2017 it had over 7,600 members worldwide, about half outside of the United States. It holds annual "world conference" meetings: The 16th will be held in Montreal, in July 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://contextualscience.org/conferences|title=Conferences|publisher=[[Association for Contextual Behavioral Science]]|accessdate=2017-11-07}}</ref>
The [[Association for Behavior Analysis]] International (ABAI) has a special interest group for practitioner issues, behavioral counseling, and clinical behavior analysis ABA:I.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} ABAI has larger special interest groups for [[autism]] and [[behavioral medicine]]. ABAI serves as the core intellectual home for behavior analysts.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Twyman |first1=J.S. |year=2007 |title=A new era of science and practice in behavior analysis |journal=Association for Behavior Analysis International: Newsletter |volume=30 |issue=3 |pages=1–4}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hassert |first1=Derrick L. |last2=Kelly |first2=Amanda N. |last3=Pritchard |first3=Joshua K. |last4=Cautilli |first4=Joseph D. |title=The Licensing of Behavior Analysts: Protecting the Profession and the Public |journal=Journal of Early and Intensive Behavior Intervention |volume=5 |issue=2 |pages=8–19 |url=http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/search/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=EJ829086&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=EJ829086 |doi=10.1037/h0100415 |year=2008}}</ref> ABAI sponsors three conferences/year—one multi-track in the U.S., one specific to Autism and one international.
The [[Association for Behavioral and Cognitive Therapies]] (ABCT) also has an interest group in [[behavior analysis]], which focuses on clinical behavior analysis. ACT work is commonly presented at ABCT and other mainstream CBT organizations.
The [[British Association for Behavioural and Cognitive Psychotherapies]] (BABCP) has a large special interest group in ACT, with over 1,200 members.
Doctoral-level behavior analysts who are psychologists belong to the [[American Psychological Association]]'s (APA) Division 25—[[Behavior analysis]].<ref>{{cite web |title=About the Behavior Analysis Division |url=http://www.apadivisions.org/division-25/about/ |website=apadivisions.org |publisher=[[American Psychological Association]] |accessdate=2018-08-07}}</ref> ACT has been called a "commonly used treatment with empirical support" within the APA-recognized specialty of behavioral and cognitive psychology.<ref>{{cite web |title=Behavioral and Cognitive Psychology Public Description |url=https://www.apa.org/ed/graduate/specialize/behav.aspx |website=apa.org |publisher=[[American Psychological Association]] |accessdate=2018-08-07}}</ref>
==See also==<!-- PLEASE RESPECT ALPHABETICAL ORDER --> * [[Behavioral psychotherapy]] * [[Contextualism]] * {{section link|Decisional balance sheet|Four square tool}} * [[Positive psychology]] * [[Solution-focused brief therapy]]

==External links== * [http://www.contextualpsychology.org/ Contextualpsychology.org] – Home for the Association for Contextual Behavioral Science, a professional organization dedicated to ACT, RFT, and functional contextualism. Also helpful for training opportunities for professionals interested in ACT and RFT. Most ACT workshops worldwide are listed here. * [http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/two-takes-depression/201102/acceptance-and-commitment-therapy An Introduction to ACT] * [http://www.blakepsychology.com/2014/04/act-self-compassion-5-ways-to-be-brave/ The ACT Formula for Self-Compassion]

In psychology, agents are goal-directed entities that are able to monitor their environment to select and perform efficient means-ends actions that are available in a given situation to achieve an intended goal. Agency, therefore, implies the ability to [[Perception|perceive]] and to change the environment of the agent (similarly to an [[intelligent agent]] designed by humans), but crucially, it also entails intentionality<ref>{{Cite book|title=The intentional stance|last=Dennett|first=Daniel|date=1987|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=978-0262040938|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=|oclc=15793656}}</ref> to represent the goal-state in the future, equifinal variability<ref>{{Cite book|title=The psychology of interpersonal relations|last=Fritz.|first=Heider|date=2015|publisher=Martino Publ|isbn=9781614277958|location=Mansfield|oclc=1033711840}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Csibra|first=Gergely|date=2008|title=Goal attribution to inanimate agents by 6.5-month-old infants|journal=Cognition|volume=107|issue=2|pages=705–717|doi=10.1016/j.cognition.2007.08.001|pmid=17869235|issn=0010-0277}}</ref> to be able to achieve the intended goal-state with different actions in different contexts, and rationality of actions in relation to their goal<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Gergely|first=György|last2=Nádasdy|first2=Zoltán|last3=Csibra|first3=Gergely|last4=Bíró|first4=Szilvia|date=1995|title=Taking the intentional stance at 12 months of age|journal=Cognition|volume=56|issue=2|pages=165–193|doi=10.1016/0010-0277(95)00661-h|issn=0010-0277}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Luo|first=Y.|last2=Baillargeon|first2=R.|date=2005|title=Can a Self-Propelled Box Have a Goal?: Psychological Reasoning in 5-Month-Old Infants|url=|journal=Psychological Science|volume=16|issue=8|pages=601–608|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9280.2005.01582.x|pmid=16102062|pmc=3351378|via=}}</ref> to produce the most efficient action available. [[Cognitive science|Cognitive]] scientists and psychologists thoroughly investigated agency attribution in humans and non-human animals, since social cognitive mechanisms as [[communication]], [[Social learning (social pedagogy)|social learning]], [[imitation]] or [[theory of mind]] presupposes the ability to identify agents and differentiate them from inanimate objects. This ability has also assumed to have a major effect on inferential and predictive processes of the observers of agents, because agentive entities are expected to perform [[Autonomy|autonomous]] behavior based on their current and previous knowledge and intentions, while inanimate objects are supposed to react to external [[Force|physical forces]].<ref name=":2">{{Citation|last=Leslie|first=Alan M.|date=1994|volume=|pages=119–148|publisher=Cambridge University Press|language=en|doi=10.1017/cbo9780511752902.006|isbn=9780511752902|title=Mapping the mind|chapter=ToMM, ToBY, and Agency: Core architecture and domain specificity}}</ref>
Although it is often confused, sensitivity to agency and the sense of agency are different concepts as the sensitivity to agency can be explained as a cognitive ability to identify agentive entities in the environment, while the [[sense of agency]] refers to the sense of control and sometimes to [[self-efficacy]], which is a learnt belief of an individual about his or her own ability to succeed in specific situations.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bandura|first=Albert|date=1982|title=Self-efficacy mechanism in human agency.|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/record/1982-25814-001|journal=American Psychologist|language=en|volume=37|issue=2|pages=122–147|doi=10.1037/0003-066x.37.2.122|issn=0003-066X}}</ref>
== Theoretical approaches of agency == According to Carey and Spelke<ref name=":3">{{Citation|last=Carey|first=Susan|title=Domain-specific knowledge and conceptual change|date=1994|work=Mapping the mind|volume=|pages=169–200|publisher=Cambridge University Press|language=en|doi=10.1017/cbo9780511752902.008|isbn=9780511752902|last2=Spelke|first2=Elizabeth}}</ref> the cognitive models explaining specific [[Perception|perceptual]] and representational abilities, for instance the models of agency recognition, can be separated into two different classes. The ''feature-based models'' of agency assume that the perceptual input of an observer consist of featural and behavioral cues that help to identify agents. Previous studies show that even very young human observers are sensitive to
* self-propulsion<ref name=":3" />, * non-rigid transformation of the object’s surface<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gibson|first=Eleanor J.|last2=Owsley|first2=Cynthia J.|last3=Johnston|first3=Joan|date=1978|title=Perception of invariants by five-month-old infants: Differentiation of two types of motion.|journal=Developmental Psychology|volume=14|issue=4|pages=407–415|doi=10.1037/0012-1649.14.4.407|issn=0012-1649}}</ref>, * irregular path movement<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Mandler|first=Jean M.|date=1992|title=How to build a baby: II. Conceptual primitives.|journal=Psychological Review|volume=99|issue=4|pages=587–604|doi=10.1037//0033-295x.99.4.587|pmid=1454900|issn=0033-295X|citeseerx=10.1.1.460.5280}}</ref>, * causation at a distance<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" />, * contingent turn-taking reactivity.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Descriptive analyses of infant communicative behavior|last=Trevarthen|first=C.|publisher=Academic Press|year=1977|isbn=|location=London|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Watson|first=John S.|date=1972|title=SMILING, COOING, AND "THE GAME"|journal=Merrill-Palmer Quarterly of Behavior and Development|volume=18|issue=4|pages=323–339|jstor=23084026}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite book|last=Movellan|first=J.R.|last2=Watson|first2=J.S.|title=The development of gaze following as a Bayesian systems identification problem|journal=Proceedings 2nd International Conference on Development and Learning. ICDL 2002|pages=34–40|language=en-US|publisher=IEEE Comput. Soc|doi=10.1109/devlrn.2002.1011728|isbn=978-0769514598|year=2002|citeseerx=10.1.1.2.1627}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Deligianni|first=Fani|last2=Senju|first2=Atsushi|last3=Gergely|first3=György|last4=Csibra|first4=Gergely|date=2011|title=Automated gaze-contingent objects elicit orientation following in 8-month-old infants.|journal=Developmental Psychology|volume=47|issue=6|pages=1499–1503|doi=10.1037/a0025659|issn=1939-0599|pmc=4636044|pmid=21942669}}</ref>
However, neither of these cues are necessary and sufficient to identify an agent<ref name=":1" />, since unfamiliar, novel entities like animated figures<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tauzin|first=Tibor|last2=Gergely|first2=György|date=2018-06-22|title=Communicative mind-reading in preverbal infants|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-27804-4|journal=Scientific Reports|language=En|volume=8|issue=1|pages=9534|doi=10.1038/s41598-018-27804-4|issn=2045-2322|pmc=6015048|pmid=29934630}}</ref> or robots without human features<ref name=":5" /> can elicit agency attribution in humans. Therefore, cognitive models belonging to the ''principle-based approaches''<ref name=":3" /> were designed to describe how humans perceive agency assuming that the detection of agency is not a precondition, but a consequence of inferential processes about potentially agentive objects.
The theory of teleological stance<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Gergely|first=György|last2=Csibra|first2=Gergely|date=2003|title=Teleological reasoning in infancy: the naı̈ve theory of rational action|url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1364661303001281|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|volume=7|issue=7|pages=287–292|doi=10.1016/s1364-6613(03)00128-1|pmid=12860186|issn=1364-6613|via=|citeseerx=10.1.1.331.5767}}</ref> proposes that from 12-month of age humans can apply the principle of rational action to determine, whether the observed entity is an agent or an inanimate object expecting that an agent behaves rationally in order to achieve its goal in a given situation. The theory assumes that the rationality principle makes observers able to relate the action, the represented goal-state and the current situational constraints to decide whether an object is an agent. For instance, if infants had learnt that an abstract, unfamiliar agent (an animated circle on a display) approaches another entity by jumping over an obstacle, when the obstacle had been removed, they expected a new, but highly rational behavior from the agent to approach the other entity via a straight pathway. In contrast, when infants were shown that the unfamiliar entity always made a detour when approaching its goal-object exhibiting non-justifiable behavior of jumping in the absence of an obstacle, they did not expect a rational of choice of behavior when the situational constraints changed.<ref name=":1" />
These results and later empirical studies<ref>{{Citation|last=Biro|first=Szilvia|title=The role of behavioral cues in understanding goal-directed actions in infancy|volume=164|date=2007|journal=Progress in Brain Research|pages=303–322|publisher=Elsevier|doi=10.1016/s0079-6123(07)64017-5|pmid=17920439|isbn=9780444530165|last2=Csibra|first2=Gergely|last3=Gergely|first3=György}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Csibra|first=Gergely|date=2008|title=Goal attribution to inanimate agents by 6.5-month-old infants|journal=Cognition|volume=107|issue=2|pages=705–717|doi=10.1016/j.cognition.2007.08.001|pmid=17869235|issn=0010-0277}}</ref><ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Luo|first=Yuyan|date=2010-09-06|title=Three-month-old infants attribute goals to a non-human agent|journal=Developmental Science|language=en|volume=14|issue=2|pages=453–460|doi=10.1111/j.1467-7687.2010.00995.x|issn=1363-755X}}</ref><ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Wagner|first=Laura|last2=Carey|first2=Susan|date=2005-01-01|title=12-Month-Old Infants Represent Probable Endings of Motion Events|journal=Infancy|language=en|volume=7|issue=1|pages=73–83|doi=10.1207/s15327078in0701_6|issn=1525-0008|citeseerx=10.1.1.140.2588}}</ref> underpinned that agency recognition in humans can be explained by principle-based models rather than simple perceptual cues. As Gergely and Csibra concluded<ref name=":6" /> from 12-month of age humans “can take the teleological stance to interpret actions as means to goals, can evaluate the relative efficiency of means by applying the principle of rational action, and can generate systematic inferences to identify relevant aspects of the situation to justify the action as an efficient means even when these aspects are not directly visible to them".
== Types of agents == It was proposed<ref name=":7">{{Citation|last=Gergely|first=György|date=2010-07-15|pages=76–105|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|language=en|doi=10.1002/9781444325485.ch3|isbn=9781444325485|title=The Wiley-Blackwell Handbook of Childhood Cognitive Development|chapter=Kinds of Agents: The Origins of Understanding Instrumental and Communicative Agency}}</ref> that the concept of agency involves different kinds of agents represented by independent cognitive systems in humans and perhaps in non-human species as well.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Tauzin|first=Tibor|last2=Csík|first2=Andor|last3=Lovas|first3=Kata|last4=Gergely|first4=György|last5=Topál|first5=József|date=2017|title=The attribution of navigational- and goal-directed agency in dogs (Canis familiaris) and human toddlers (Homo sapiens).|journal=Journal of Comparative Psychology|volume=131|issue=1|pages=1–9|doi=10.1037/com0000053|pmid=28182482|issn=1939-2087|url=http://real.mtak.hu/79227/1/2017_Tauzin_etal_JoCP_accepted_manuscript_u.pdf}}</ref> In humans, the species-specific social environment allows to identify agents either based on non-communicative observation of their rational, goal-directed actions or by relying on their communicative behavior which they exchange with other agents. In non-human species, however, none of these types of input information are necessary, since unfamiliar agents can be recognized simply on the basis of their perceptual abilities, which has context-dependent effect on their behavior even in the absence a visible goal-object that may be required to assess the efficiency of goal-approach.
=== Instrumental agency === According to Gergely<ref name=":7" /> instrumental agents are intentional agents that exhibit actions in order to realize their goal states in the environment. The recognition of instrumental agents is investigated by numerous experiments in human infants<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":12" /><ref name=":13" /><ref>{{Citation|last=Biro|first=Szilvia|title=The role of behavioral cues in understanding goal-directed actions in infancy|volume=164|date=2007|journal=Progress in Brain Research|pages=303–322|publisher=Elsevier|doi=10.1016/s0079-6123(07)64017-5|pmid=17920439|isbn=9780444530165|last2=Csibra|first2=Gergely|last3=Gergely|first3=György}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Csibra|first=Gergely|last2=Bíró|first2=Szilvia|last3=Koós|first3=Orsolya|last4=Gergely|first4=György|date=2003|title=One-year-old infants use teleological representations of actions productively|journal=Cognitive Science|language=en|volume=27|issue=1|pages=111–133|doi=10.1207/s15516709cog2701_4|issn=0364-0213}}</ref>, and also in non-human apes.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Rochat|first=Magali J.|last2=Serra|first2=Elisabetta|last3=Fadiga|first3=Luciano|last4=Gallese|first4=Vittorio|date=2008|title=The Evolution of Social Cognition: Goal Familiarity Shapes Monkeys' Action Understanding|journal=Current Biology|volume=18|issue=3|pages=227–232|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2007.12.021|pmid=18221878|issn=0960-9822}}</ref><ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Uller|first=Claudia|date=2003-12-18|title=Disposition to recognize goals in infant chimpanzees|journal=Animal Cognition|language=en|volume=7|issue=3|pages=154–61|doi=10.1007/s10071-003-0204-9|pmid=14685823|issn=1435-9448}}</ref><ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Wood|first=Justin N.|last2=Glynn|first2=David D.|last3=Phillips|first3=Brenda C.|last4=Hauser|first4=Marc D.|date=2007-09-07|title=The Perception of Rational, Goal-Directed Action in Nonhuman Primates|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/317/5843/1402|journal=Science|language=en|volume=317|issue=5843|pages=1402–1405|doi=10.1126/science.1144663|issn=0036-8075|pmid=17823353}}</ref>
=== Communicative agency === In contrast to instrumental agents, communicative agents<ref>{{Citation|last=Gergely|first=György|title=Reasoning about Instrumental and Communicative Agency in Human Infancy|date=2012|work=Rational Constructivism in Cognitive Development|pages=59–94|publisher=Elsevier|doi=10.1016/b978-0-12-397919-3.00003-4|isbn=9780123979193|last2=Jacob|first2=Pierre|url=https://jeannicod.ccsd.cnrs.fr/ijn_00756294/file/Gergely_Jacob_2012_in_Rational_Constructivism.pdf}}</ref> are intentional agents whose actions are performed to bring about a specific change in the mental representations of the addressee, for instance by providing new and relevant information. The recognition of communicative agency may allow for the observer to predict that communicative information transfer can have a relevant effect on the behavior of the agent, even if the interacting agents and their communicative signals are unfamiliar.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tauzin|first=Tibor|last2=Gergely|first2=György|date=2018-06-22|title=Communicative mind-reading in preverbal infants|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-27804-4|journal=Scientific Reports|language=En|volume=8|issue=1|pages=9534|doi=10.1038/s41598-018-27804-4|issn=2045-2322|pmc=6015048|pmid=29934630}}</ref>
=== Navigational agency === The [[Construals|construal]] of navigational agency is based on the assumption that Leslie’s theory<ref name=":2" /> on agency implies two different types of distal sensitivity; distal sensitivity in space and distal sensitivity in time. While goal-directed instrumental agents need both of these abilities to represent a goal-state in the future and achieve it in a rational and efficient manner, navigational agents are supposed to have only perceptual abilities, that is a distal sensitivity in space to avoid collision with objects in their environments. A study<ref name=":8" /> contrasting the ability of dogs and human infants to attribute agency to unfamiliar self-propelled object showed that dogs – unlike human infants – may lack the capability to recognize instrumental agents, however they can identify navigational agents.
== Agency recognition in non-human animals == The ability to represent the efficiency of goal-directed actions of an instrumental agent may be a phylogenetically ancient core cognitive mechanism<ref>{{Cite book|title=The origin of concepts|last=Susan.|first=Carey|date=2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195367638|location=Oxford|oclc=233697385}}</ref> that can be found in non-human primates as well. Previous research provided evidence for this assumption showing that this sensitivity affects the expectations of cotton-top tamarins, rhesus macaques, and chimpanzees.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":10" /><ref name=":11" /> Non-human apes are able to make inferences about the goal of an instrumental agent by taking the environmental constraints that can guide the agents’ actions into account. Moreover, it seems that non-human species like dogs can recognize contingent reactivity as an abstract of cue of agency, and respond to contingent agent significantly different in contrast to inanimate objects.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tauzin|first=Tibor|last2=Kovács|first2=Krisztina|last3=Topál|first3=József|date=2016-07-19|title=Dogs Identify Agents in Third-Party Interactions on the Basis of the Observed Degree of Contingency|journal=Psychological Science|language=en|volume=27|issue=8|pages=1061–1068|doi=10.1177/0956797616647518|pmid=27268590|issn=0956-7976|url=http://real.mtak.hu/79227/1/2017_Tauzin_etal_JoCP_accepted_manuscript_u.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gergely|first=Anna|last2=Petró|first2=Eszter|last3=Topál|first3=József|last4=Miklósi|first4=Ádám|date=2013-08-28|title=What Are You or Who Are You? The Emergence of Social Interaction between Dog and an Unidentified Moving Object (UMO)|journal=PLoS ONE|language=en|volume=8|issue=8|pages=e72727|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0072727|issn=1932-6203|pmc=3755977|pmid=24015272}}</ref>

{{advert|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox Sculpture | image = [[Image:Always Becoming Facing West.JPG|200px]] | title = Always Becoming | artist = [[Nora Naranjo-Morse]] | year = 2007 | type = Dirt, sand, straw, clay,
stone, black locust wood,
bamboo, grass, and yam vines. | city = [[Washington, D.C.]] | museum =
[[National Museum of the American Indian]] }} '''''Always Becoming''''' is an artwork created in 2007 by [[Nora Naranjo-Morse]] (born 1953), a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] [[Pottery|Potter]] and [[poet]]. She currently resides in [[Española, New Mexico|Española]], [[New Mexico]], just north of [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]] and is a member of the [[Santa Clara Pueblo]]. ==Description== The sculpture consists of five separate sculptures, that make up a family. Grounded in figures from [[Santa Clara Pueblo]] oral tradition the sculptures are named: * Father * Mother * Little one * Moon Woman * Mountain Bird The sculptures were built in-situ over the summer of 2007, Nora Naranjo-Morse worked with her niece Athena Swentzell Steen and her husband Bill Steen who are experts at building structures with natural material, and the family of Don Juan Morales ([[Tepehuan]]) from the Mexican state of [[Durango]], as well as many volunteers including museum staff and visitors. {{quote|Being strangers at the beginning of this journey, we came from distant places with the intent to build sculptures, and in the process built a family as well.|Nora Naranajo-Morse, 2007 {{Cite web|url=http://www.nmai.si.edu/alwaysbecoming/AlwaysBecoming.html|title=NMAI: NORA NARANJO-MORSE-ALWAYS BECOMING MALL SCULPTURE PROJECT|website=www.nmai.si.edu|access-date=2017-01-10}}}} ==Materials== The Sculptures are made entirely of natural materials: dirt, sand, straw, clay, stone, black locust wood, bamboo, grass, and yam vines. These natural elements were selected to take on a life of their own and thus affect the sculptures over time. In this way the materials ensure the forms are 'always becoming'. ==Dimensions== The five sculptures range in size from seven and a half to sixteen feet tall. ==History and Location== On May 24, 2006, the [[National Museum of the American Indian]] announced that Naranjo-Morse had won its outdoor sculpture design competition. "Always Becoming" was selected unanimously from more than 55 entries submitted by Native artists from throughout the Western Hemisphere.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nmai.si.edu/press/releases/2006-05-24_outdoor_sculpture_release_final_1.pdf|title=Press {{!}} National Museum of the American Indian|website=www.nmai.si.edu|access-date=2017-01-10}} During the summer of 2007, on the grounds of the National Museum of the American Indian, [[Washington, DC]], Naranjo-Morse built a family of clay sculptures. The commissioned work is located on the 'Native landscape' at the museum's south entrance on Maryland Avenue S.W. near 4th Street and Independence Avenue S.W., Washington, D.C. A public dedication, officially opening these public works of art, took place on September 1, 2007. The sculptures are intended to disintegrate over time, and the lives of sculptures from the initial idea through the continued process of [[stewardship]] are being documented by Filmmaker Dax Thomas ([[Laguna Pueblo|Laguna]]/[[Acoma Pueblo|Acoma]]). As the sculptures disintegrate the films of their life will form a more permanent record of their existence and are therefore an essential part of the artistic process, and the work of art itself.{{Cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/quatica|title=quatica|website=Vimeo|access-date=2017-01-10}} {{quote|Native culture and the environment served as the inspiration for the sculpture design. 'Always Becoming' will reflect themes of growth and adaptation and represent indigenous peoples' unique relationship to the environment, ... The sculpture's metaphor of home and family not only conveys a universal theme to all peoples, but also enhances the visitors' experience that they have entered a Native place when they {{sic|step foot}} on the museum grounds.|Nora Naranajo-Morse, 2007 {{Cite web|url=http://www.caneloproject.com/pages/currrent%20projects/smithsonian.html|title=always becoming|website=www.caneloproject.com|access-date=2017-01-10}} }} ==See also== * [[List of public art in Washington, D.C., Ward 2]] ==References== ==External links== [[File:Asemic3.jpg|right|thumb|Asemic writing from Marco Giovenale]] '''Asemic writing''' is a [[word]]less open [[Semantics|semantic]] form of [[writing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://postasemicpress.blogspot.com/2017/04/works-interviews-by-michael-jacobson-is.html|author=Michael Jacobson|title=Works & Interviews}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asemic.net/|title=Tim Gaze. Asemic Magazine|work=Asemic Magazine}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fullofcrow.com/prate/2009/11/tim-gaze/|title=Full Of Crow Tim Gaze interview}}</ref> The word ''asemic'' means "having no specific semantic content", or "without the smallest unit of meaning".<ref>From [[Greek language|Greek]]: asemos (αόεμoβ) = without sign, unmarked, obscure, or ignoble.</ref> With the non-specificity of asemic writing there comes a vacuum of meaning, which is left for the reader to fill in and interpret. All of this is similar to the way one would deduce meaning from an [[abstract art|abstract work of art]]. Where asemic writing differs from abstract art is in the asemic author's use of gestural constraint, and the retention of physical characteristics of writing such as lines and symbols. Asemic writing is a hybrid art form that fuses [[Writing|text]] and [[image]] into a unity, and then sets it free to arbitrary subjective interpretations. It may be compared to [[free writing]] or writing for its own sake, instead of writing to produce verbal context. The open nature of asemic works allows for meaning to occur across [[linguistic]] understanding; an asemic text may be "read" in a similar fashion regardless of the reader's natural language.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scriptjr.nl/issues/1.1/satu-kaikkonen-1-1.php|work=SCRIPTjr.nl|title=Satu Kaikkonen interview}}</ref> Multiple meanings for the same [[symbol]]ism are another possibility for an asemic work, that is, asemic writing can be polysemantic or have [[zero]] meaning, [[infinity|infinite]] meanings, or its meaning can [[Evolution (term)|evolve]] over time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://samplekanon.com/?p=1946/|title=Samplekannon interview with Michael Jacobson|work=Samplekannon}}</ref> Asemic works leave for the reader to decide how to [[translate]] and [[Exploration|explore]] an asemic text; in this sense, the reader becomes co-creator of the asemic work.
In 1997 [[Visual poetry|visual poets]] Tim Gaze and Jim Leftwich first applied the word ''asemic'' to name their quasi-calligraphic writing gestures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://galatearesurrects2018.blogspot.com/2018/02/featured-essay-by-jim-leftwich.html|title=Galatea Resurrects: The Nearness Of Asemic Writing by Jim Leftwich}}</ref> They then began to distribute them to [[poetry]] [[magazines]] both [[online]] and in print. The authors explored sub-verbal and sub-letteral forms of writing, and textual [[asemia]] as a creative option and as an intentional practice. Since the late 1990s, asemic writing has blossomed into a worldwide literary/[[art movement]]. It has especially grown in the early part of the 21st century, though there is an acknowledgement of a long and complex history, which precedes the activities of the current asemic movement, especially with regards to abstract calligraphy, wordless writing, and verbal writing damaged beyond the point of legibility. Jim Leftwich has recently stated that an asemic condition of an asemic work is an impossible goal, and that it is not possible to create an art/literary work entirely without meaning. He has begun to use the term "pansemic" to describe this type of work.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://slowforward.wordpress.com/2016/03/13/jim-leftwich-asemic-writing-definitions-and-contexts-1998-2016/|title=Jim Leftwich: “asemic writing definitions and contexts, 1998-2016”}}</ref> Others such as author [[Travis Jeppesen]] have found the term ''asemic'' to be problematic because "it seems to infer writing with no meaning."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sleek-mag.com/2016/12/02/hans-ulrich-obrist-zhang-jeppesen-miralda/|title=Hans Ulrich Obrist in Conversation About Inventing New Languages|work=Sleek Magazine}}</ref>
==Styles of asemic writing== [[File:Crazyzhangxu.jpg|thumb|An example of Zhang Xu's calligraphy]]
Asemic writing exists in many different forms. It is often created with a [[pen]] or [[brush]], but can range from being hand drawn in the sand with a stick and documented by [[photography]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/life/arts-and-entertainment/2018-04-03-cape-town-artist-andrew-van-der-merwe-carves-out-beach-calligraphy-niche/|title=Cape Town artist Andrew van der Merwe carves out beach calligraphy niche|work=BusinessDay|author=Thelma Mort}}</ref> or to works on [[canvas]], [[paper]], [[computer]] images, and [[animations]]. The key to asemic writing is that even though it is traditionally "unreadable" it still maintains a strong attractive appeal to the reader's [[eye]]. Various asemic writing includes [[pictograms]], or [[ideograms]] the meanings of which are sometimes suggested by their shapes, though it may also flow as an [[abstract expressionist]] scribble which resembles writing but avoids words. Asemic writing, at times, exists as a conception or shadow of conventional writing practices. Reflecting writing, but not completely existing as a traditional writing system, asemic writing seeks to make the reader hover in a state between reading and looking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehandstand.org/archive//january2006/articles/nonismacemicart.htm|author=Jaime Morrison|title=Nonism: Asemic Art}}</ref> Asemic writing has no verbal sense, though it may have clear textual sense.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dbqp.blogspot.com/2005/11/varieties-of-visual-poetry.html|title=Varieties of Visual Poetry|work=dbqp|author=Geof Huth}}</ref> Through its formatting and structure, asemic writing may suggest a type of document and, thereby, suggest a meaning. The form of art is still writing, often [[calligraphic]] in form, and either depends on a reader's sense and knowledge of writing systems for it to make sense,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dbqp.blogspot.com/2005/11/varieties-of-visual-poetry.html|title=Varieties of Visual Poetry|work=dbqp|author=Geof Huth}}</ref> or can be understood through aesthetic intuition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://postasemicpress.blogspot.com/2017/04/works-interviews-by-michael-jacobson-is.html|author=Michael Jacobson|title=Works & Interviews}}</ref> True asemic writing occurs when the creator of the asemic piece cannot read their own asemic writing. Relative asemic writing is a natural writing system that can be read by some people but not by everyone (e.g. [[ciphers]], [[wildstyle]], etc.). Most asemic writing lies between these two extremes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fullofcrow.com/prate/2009/08/michael-jacobson/|title=PRATE, Michael Jacobson interview|publisher=Fullofcrow.com|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref> Influences on asemic writing are illegible, [[Constructed language|invented]], or primal [[manuscript|script]]s ([[cave painting]]s, [[doodle]]s, children's drawings, etc.). But instead of being thought of as mimicry of preliterate expression, asemic writing may be considered to be a global [[Postliterate society|postliterate]] style of writing that uses all forms of creativity for inspiration. Other influences on asemic writing are [[alien language in science fiction|alien languages in science fiction]], [[artistic languages]], [[sigil (magic)|sigils]] (magick), [[undeciphered scripts]], and [[graffiti]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scriptjr.nl/special-sections/cryptotexts/michael-jacobson-interview#.VBCXA2Nrucs|work=SCRIPTjr.nl|title=Michael Jacobson interview| accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref> Uses for asemic writing include mental and [[Creativity|creative]] [[idea]] stimulation, [[non-verbal communication]], [[hoaxes]], and general authorial self-expression.
===History===
[[File:MirthaDermisacheNewsletter.jpg|thumb|left | Newsletter from Mirtha Dermisache<ref>dermisache-9 Newsletters & 1 Reportaje 2000: Newsletter, 2000 from Mirtha Dermisache, Nueve Newsletters & Un Reportaje, Buenos Aires : El borde, Marseille : Mobil-Home, Montpellier : Manglar, 2004. Offset printing, 440 copies.</ref>]] Asemic writing occurs in [[avant-garde]] literature and art with strong roots in the [[Proto-writing|earliest forms of writing]]. The history of today's asemic movement stems from two [[China|Chinese]] calligraphers: "crazy" [[Zhang Xu]], a [[Tang Dynasty]] (circa 800 CE) calligrapher who was famous for creating wild illegible calligraphy, and the younger "drunk" [[monk]] [[Huaisu]] who also excelled at illegible [[Cursive script (East Asia)|cursive]] calligraphy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://centerforbookarts.blogspot.com/2014/07/making-sense-of-asemic-writing.html|title=Center for Book Arts: Making Sense of Asemic Writing|author=Sarah Nicholls|publisher=Centerforbookarts.blogspot.com|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref> [[Japanese people|Japanese]] calligraphers subsequently expanded upon Chinese abstract calligraphic expression by [[Hitsuzendō]] (the way of [[Zen]] through brush), allowing their works to move past formal presentation and "breathe with the vitality of eternal experience". During the 18th century the [[Ireland|Irish]] author [[Laurence Sterne]] included asemic lines in his novel ''[[The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman]]'' (1759), adding the graphic device to help tell the [[Narrative|story]] "in a tolerably straight line". In the 1920s [[Man Ray]], who was influenced by [[Dada]], created an early work of wordless writing with his poem ''[[Paris]], Mai 1924'', which is nothing more than dashes on a page. Later in the 1920s, [[Henri Michaux]], who was influenced by Asian calligraphy, [[Surrealism]], and [[Automatic writing]], began to create wordless works such as ''Alphabet'' (1925) and ''Narration'' (1927).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://natalieferrisdotcom.wordpress.com/2014/01/26/leaking-the-squalls-the-art-and-letters-of-henri-michaux/|title=‘Leaking the Squalls': The Art and Letters of Henri Michaux|work=natalie ferris|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref> Michaux referred to his calligraphic works as "interior Gestures". The writer and artist [[Wassily Kandinsky]] was an early precursor to asemic writing, with his linear piece ''Indian Story'' (1931) exemplifying complete textual abstraction. In the 1950s there is [[Brion Gysin]] (whose calligraphy was influenced by [[Arabic]] and Japanese calligraphy), [[Isidore Isou]] (who founded [[Lettrisme]]), [[Cy Twombly]] (a former US Army [[Cryptologist]]), and [[Morita Shiryū]]/[[Bokujin-kai]] Group (Ink Human Society)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vermillionmedia.blogspot.com/2013/08/calligraphy-bokujin-kai-group-and.html|title= Calligraphy The Bokujin-Kai Group and Shiryu Morita|publisher=infinity of utterances kathryn simon phd}}</ref> all of whom expanded writing into illegible, abstract, and wordless visual mark-making; they would help lay the foundation for asemic writers of the future. [[Mira Schendel]] was an artist from [[Brazil]] who created many illegible works over the course of her life, for example her piece ''Archaic Writing'' (1964). [[Mirtha Dermisache]] is another writer who had created asemic writing since the 1960s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jacket2.org/commentary/witness-mirtha-dermisache|title=Witness Mirtha Dermisache|publisher=Jacket2.org|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref> Dermisache actively said that even though her graphisms have no meaning, they still retained the full rights of an autonomous work. 1971 was the year when [[:fr:Alain Satié|Alain Satié]] released his work ''Écrit en prose ou L'Œuvre hypergraphique'' which contains asemic writing throughout the entire graphic novel.<ref>Alain Satie, Écrit en Prose, Éditions PSI, 1971.</ref> [[León Ferrari]] was another artist/poet who created many asemic works in the 1960s and 70s, such as ''Escritura'' (1976).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.printmag.com/illustration/the-writing-of-art-the-art-of-writing/|author=Buzz Poole|title=The Writing of Art, The Art of Writing|publisher=Printmag.com}}</ref> 1974 saw the release of [[Max Ernst]]'s work ''Maximiliana: The Illegal Practice Of Astronomy: hommage à Dorothea Tanning''; this book is a major influence on asemic writers such as Tim Gaze, Michael Jacobson, and [[Derek Beaulieu]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fullofcrow.com/prate/2009/08/michael-jacobson/|title=PRATE|publisher=Fullofcrow.com|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref> [[Roland Barthes]] was also involved with asemic writing; he titled his asemic works Contre-écritures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theparisreview.org/blog/2012/12/05/vispo/|title=Vispo|author=Tierra Innovation|publisher=Theparisreview.org|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drawingsonwriting.org/page25.htm|title=Drawings on Writing|publisher=Drawingsonwriting.org|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref>
A modern example of asemic writing is [[Luigi Serafini (artist)|Luigi Serafini]]'s ''[[Codex Seraphinianus]]'' (1981). Serafini described the script of the Codex as asemic in a talk at the [[Oxford University Society of Bibliophiles]] held on May 8, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jeff Stanley|date=2010|title=To Read Images Not Words: Computer-Aided Analysis of the Handwriting in the Codex Seraphinianus (MSc dissertation)|publisher=North Carolina State University at Raleigh|pages=8–9|accessdate=9 April 2012|url=http://repository.lib.ncsu.edu/ir/bitstream/1840.16/6460/1/etd.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> In the 1980s [[Chinese people|Chinese]] artist [[Xu Bing]] created ''Tiānshū'', or ''[[A Book from the Sky]]'' which is a work of books and hanging scrolls on which were printed 4000 hand carved meaningless characters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://crab.wordpress.com/2008/07/02/free-writing/|title=Free writing|work=stalker|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref> The 1980s also saw artist [[Gu Wenda]] begin the first of a series of projects centered on the invention of meaningless, false Chinese ideograms, depicted as if they were truly old and traditional. One exhibition of this type was held in [[Xi'an]] in 1986, featuring paintings of fake ideograms on a massive scale.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://lacon4.wordpress.com/tag/asemic-writing-2/|title=asemic writing - Donna Tull|publisher=Lacon4.wordpress.com|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref> Also in China, during the 1990s, an abstract calligraphy movement known as "Calligraphy-ism" came into existence, a leading proponent of this movement being Luo Qi. Calligraphy-ism is an aesthetic movement that aims to develop calligraphy into an abstract art. The characters do not need to retain their traditional forms or be legible as words. In [[Vietnam]] during the [[2000s (decade)|2000s]] a calligraphy group called the Zenei Gang of Five appeared. To this group of young artists, “Wordless” means that which cannot be said, that which is both before and beyond the specificity of naming. To be without words is saying nothing and saying everything.

and there is asemic writing produced by [[artificial intelligence]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kanno.so/asemic-languages/ |title=Asemic AI}}</ref>
Satu Kaikkonen, a contemporary asemic artist/writer from [[Finland]], had this to say about asemic writing:
{{Quotation|As a creator of asemics, I consider myself an explorer and a global storyteller. Asemic art, after all, represents a kind of language that's universal and lodged deep within our unconscious minds. Regardless of language identity, each human's initial attempts to create written language look very similar and, often, quite asemic. In this way, asemic art can serve as a sort of common language—albeit an abstract, post-literate one—that we can use to understand one another regardless of background or nationality. For all its limping-functionality, semantic language all too often divides and asymmetrically empowers while asemic texts can't help but put people of all literacy-levels and identities on equal footing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scriptjr.nl/issues/1.1/satu-kaikkonen-1-1.php|title=SCRIPTjr.nl|work=SCRIPTjr.nl|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref>}}
[[Bruce Sterling]] comments about asemic writing on his [[Wired magazine]] blog ''Beyond the Beyond'': {{Quotation|Writing that doesn’t have any actual writing in it whatsoever. You would think that this must be some kind of ultimate literary frontier, a frozen [[Antarctica]] of writing entirely devoid of literary content, but I wonder.
What is “beyond asemic writing”? Maybe a neural brain-scan of an author *thinking about* asemic writing. Maybe *generative asemic writing*. Maybe “asemic biomimicry”. Maybe nanoasemic writing inscribed with atomic force microscopes by Artificial Intelligences.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/2009/07/web-semantics-asemic-writing/ |title=Web Semantics: Asemic writing |date=July 13, 2009 |last=Sterling |first=Bruce |work=[[Wired.com]] |accessdate=February 29, 2016}}</ref>}}
==False writing systems== '''False writing systems''' are artificially constructed [[alphabet]]s or scripts used (sometimes within the context of a [[false document]]) to convey a degree of [[wikt:verisimilitude|verisimilitude]]. Examples of this include alien dialogue in comic strips, [[animated cartoons]], and [[graphic novel]]s (such as [[Alan Moore]]'s ''[[The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen]]'', and the ''[[Valérian and Laureline]]'' series). The script in [[Luigi Serafini (artist)|Luigi Serafini]]'s 1981 ''[[Codex Seraphinianus]]'' was confirmed by the author to have no occult meaning. The [[Voynich manuscript]], a mysterious work on which the ''Codex Seraphinianus'' was likely based, uses an [[undeciphered writing system]] that some speculated to be false.
